Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Algorithms and Modeling for Chemotactic Deformable Particles in Non-Newtonian, Multiphase, Non-Isothermal, Turbulent Flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project concerns computational fluid dynamics in the field of fluid-structure interactions. The goal of the research is to develop a new multi-scale computationally-efficient and robust numerical model to simulate particles that move in response to chemical stimuli in their environment. The work aims to create new understanding of the hydrodynamic interactions of such particles with the bulk fluid, which differs from particle-fluid hydrodynamics for non-chemotactic particles, whose motility is driven solely by the bulk fluid flow. The project will recruit a diverse group of talented undergraduate students and encourage them to pursue graduate studies, focusing on challenging research problems in a well-established interdisciplinary environment. The project will introduce students to the intellectual excitement of computational and mathematical research in fluid dynamics, thereby encouraging them to think creatively and independently about potential applications and increasing their awareness of pathways to graduate schools and opportunities in research and development in industry employment.

This project explores a new multi-scale computationally-efficient and robust numerical model to simulate two- and three-dimensional motility of deformable chemotactic particles in complex fluids. This addresses two fundamental issues that arise in the mathematical and computational treatment of particle motility in fluids: (i) self-autonomous motion of deformable chemotactic particles in response to spatially- and temporally-varying chemoattractant gradients, and (ii) particle-fluid hydrodynamics in non-Newtonian fluids and multiphase flows in laminar to turbulent flow regimes. The multi-scale model couples intracellular signaling pathways with particle-fluid interactions using the RapidCell model, the method of Regularized Stokeslets, and the Immersed Boundary method. This is well-suited for sophisticated applications, including, for example, bacterial chemotaxis promoting biofilm formation and swarm robotic odor localization. The project includes development of a novel, multi-scale computational fluid dynamics package suitable for theoretical analyses and diverse multi-disciplinary applications. It will serve as a highly informative teaching tool for graduate and undergraduate level classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF grant (DMS-1720323) has resulted in

1)    Successful training of 12 students (6 were fully supported by the grant while others were partially supported or worked on the projects crafted from the proposal):

The PI prioritized recruitment of at least one female student every year and reached out to talented undergraduate students in all STEM fields. Some of these students belonged to underrepresented groups or were first-generation college students. The students got involved in every aspect of computational science research; some of them became motivated to go to graduate school to further their education. The PI?s successful training activities also extend to undergraduates at other universities as well, including internationally (Vietnam International University in Hanoi). Most of these students received travel awards or presented their research work at different conferences. Overall, the grant has brought significant impact on educating our undergraduates and supporting faculty and student interdisciplinary research activities.

2)    Publications (one joint with Dr. Mimi Koehl at UC Berkeley and Dr. Lisa Fauci at Tulane, and 2 undergraduates at Trinity on choanoflagellate swimming and feeding ? published in 2019; and the other one joint with Dr. Hakan Basagaoglu at Edwards Aquifer Authority, Dr. Orrin Shindell in the Physics department at Trinity, and one undergraduate at Trinity on biofilm growth and deformation ? submitted for review in June 2021):

These two papers not only required intensive training for students on Fluid-Structure Interactions (FSI) but also established two important types of project work and interdisciplinary collaborations for the PI. Through these projects, the PI was able to extend her knowledge in FSI to incorporate experimental measurements and conducted simulations in systematic ways that are not possible with lab experiments. The simulation results helped us gain further insights into these complex biological systems. We are working on three more papers related to the hydrodynamics of choanoflagellates and bacteria due to this grant.

3)    Meaningful multi-disciplinary collaborations:

The PI has formed strong collaborations with Dr. Shindell in Physics, Dr. Healy in Biology at Trinity. She also successfully extended her collaborations with Drs. Fauci and Cortez at Tulane, Dr. Koehl at Berkeley, Dr. Rodenborn at Centre College, and Dr. Basagaoglu at Edwards Aquifer Authority. These collaborations are based on meaningful communications between experimental investigations and mathematical modeling to tackle these challenging problems.

4)    Further opportunities for research funding:

The NSF grant (DMS-1720323) has motivated the PI and her collaborators to apply for other collaborative grants from the DMS/NIGMS Initiative to Support Research at the Interface of the Biological and Mathematical Sciences. The PI recently received a joint award with Drs. Fauci and Cortez at Tulane, and Dr. Koehl at Berkeley. She is writing another proposal with Dr. Shindell and Dr. Healy at Trinity, and Dr. Rodenborn at Centre College.

5)    Staying at the cutting edge of the computational fluid dynamics field in a liberal arts environment:

Through the interdisciplinary collaborations, the PI has learned and developed advanced numerical techniques which are beyond undergraduate training. For example, in the choanoflagellate project, while working with undergraduates on single-celled and small-colony models, the PI also closely work with Drs. Fauci and Cortez at Tulane on the development, implementation, and validation of the numerical methods related to a big colony. Without NSF funding, the PI wouldn?t have been able to reduce her teaching load to 2:3 to have time to train students and pursue her research interests, to present her collaborative work at national/international conferences, or to have the freedom to offer research stipends to talented undergraduates at Trinity University.
